This assistant provides general guidance on recent Zambian tax changes for 2025, including income tax, VAT, Smart Invoice requirements, turnover tax, mobile money levy and other topics covered in Practice Note No. 1 of 2025. It does not replace the law or official ZRA advice.

training_phrases: What is the Zambia Revenue Authority?
responses: ZRA is the statutory body that administers and collects taxes and related levies in Zambia, including income tax, VAT, customs and excise duties, and specific charges like the mobile money transaction levy.
ZRA ni boma body ifyo ili kukukwata na kulemeka amisonkho na related levies mu Zambia, pantu income tax, VAT, customs na excise duties, na specific charges nga mobile money transaction levy.
ZRA's mission is to optimise and sustain revenue collection and administration for a prosperous Zambia.
ZRA's vision is to be a world class model of excellence in revenue administration and trade facilitation.
The ZRA tagline is: "My Tax, Your Tax, Our Destiny".
ZRA's mission ni kukukwata na kusunga revenue collection na administration for a prosperous Zambia.
ZRA's vision ni ku ba world class model of excellence mu revenue administration na trade facilitation.
ZRA tagline ni: "My Tax, Your Tax, Our Destiny".
Lumela, utamboke ku Zambia Revenue Authority virtual assistant. Ninga ku gwase buti luno?
Mlumeleng, iyi ni ZRA assistant. Buuza buti ka mitelo ya 2025, Smart Invoice, VAT kana minwe ya ZRA.
Na pila hande, wena u pila cwang?
Ni itumezi, mutozi chwani luno?
Kozo, ni hande. Ninga ku gwase buti ka ZRA luno?
Ni itumezi. Buuza buti ka Smart Invoice kana mitelo.

Assistant ye yi pelela manyalo ka mitelo ye shanguluka mu Zambia ka 2025, ki mitelo ya malgashi (income tax), VAT, Smart Invoice, turnover tax, mobile money levy ni minwe, ho ya ka Practice Note No. 1 ya 2025. A si mulayo, bantu ba sa shuwa ku kopa manyalo ka ZRA ka bo ndate ba mitelo.

training_phrases: ZRA mulimo wa bone ni yini?
responses: ZRA ki bulukani ya mmuso ye i bokang ni ku fumanya mitelo ni mabeli a yone mu Zambia, ho akarelwa income tax, VAT, customs ni excise duties ni mabeli a ma transaction ya mobile money.

training_phrases: ZRA ba lakanya cinwi mu bulao?
responses: Mission ya ZRA ki ku ntumisa ni ku tswaleletsa kupila mitelo ni malango a yone ho u sila Zambia ye lipile hande.
Vision ya ZRA ki ku ba muenzelo wa boloka mu kupila mitelo ni ho ntumisa bohema.
Tagline ya ZRA ki: "My Tax, Your Tax, Our Destiny".
Moni, muli bwanji? Takulandirani ku Zambia Revenue Authority virtual assistant. Ndingakuthandizeni bwanji lero?
Takulandirani ku ZRA assistant. Funsani za kusintha kwa misonkho ya 2025, Smart Invoice, VAT kapena ntchito zina za ZRA.

Simalowa m'malo mwa malamulo kapena upangiri wovomerezeka wa ZRA.

training_phrases: Kodi Zambia Revenue Authority ndi chiyani?
responses: ZRA ndi bungwe la boma lomwe limayang'anira ndi kusonkhanitsa misonkho ndi ma levy osiyanasiyana ku Zambia, kuphatikiza income tax, VAT, customs ndi excise duties, komanso ma levy apadera monga mobile money transaction levy.
Mission ya ZRA ndi kukonza ndiponso kusunga bwino kusonkhanitsa misonkho ndi kayendetsedwe ka misonkho kuti Zambia ipite patsogolo.

training_phrases: My Tax Your Tax Our Destiny
responses: ZRA's tagline is: 'My Tax, Your Tax, Our Destiny'

training_phrases: What does the practice note cover?
responses: Practice Note No. 1/2025 describes changes introduced by 11 Acts/Regulations effective January 1, 2025. Key changes include: Advance Income Tax on remittances, turnover tax threshold increased to K5M, VAT threshold maintained at K800K, input tax restricted to smart invoices, electricity production up to 100kWh without licence.

training_phrases: Is this practice note legally binding?
Can I use this in court?
responses: The commentary in the Practice Note is for general guidance only and is not to be taken as legal authority in any proceedings. The information is not exhaustive and does not affect any person's right of appeal on tax liability, nor does it preclude any discretionary treatment allowed under the law.

Key definition changes in Income Tax Act:
1. 'Approved fund' now means a pension scheme registered under Pension Scheme Regulation Act
2. 'Private fund' means a private fund authorized by Securities and Exchange Commission under Securities Act 2016
3. 'Pensionable terms' extended to all approved funds (not just pension funds)
4. Definitions of 'approved annuity contract' and 'approved pension fund' deleted
5. 'Securities and Exchange Commission' definition added

training_phrases: How much loss can I deduct?
responses:
Section 30 amended: Losses can only be deducted from 50% of taxable income in the charge year. Previously applied only to mining; now applies to ALL businesses.

Example: K800,000 loss in 2024, K150,000 income in 2025:
• 50% of income: K75,000
• Loss offset: K75,000
• Taxable amount: K75,000
• Loss carried forward: K725,000

Any excess loss carried forward can only offset 50% of income in subsequent years.
Section 37 amended to remove reference to the repealed Fourth Schedule. Deduction allowed for any amount paid by employer by way of contribution to an approved fund.
Section 43E amended: Skills Development Levy is deductible even where the levy due has not been paid to ZRA. Previously required actual payment.

Section 45B amended - entities now requiring TPIN:
• Water utility companies: Account opening/holding
• Mobile money operators: Account opening/holding
• Mobile network operators: Account opening/holding
• Internet service providers: Account opening/holding
• NHIMA: Account opening/holding
• NAPSA: Account opening/holding
• Professional bodies: Membership registration, subscription, renewal
• Local Authorities: Registration of title deed
Section 46A(5) amended: Commissioner-General may waive whole or part of 25% penalty for understatement of income in provisional return if satisfied with reasons for understatement.

Turnover Tax changes:
• Threshold increased from K800,000 to K5,000,000 (Section 64A)
• Rate: 5% on turnover above K12,000 up to K5,000,000
• Applies to persons with annual turnover ≤ K5M
• Also applies to gig economy with same threshold

Exclusions remain: partnerships, consultancy, mining, voluntary VAT registrants.

Note: VAT threshold unchanged at K800,000. Taxpayers with turnover between K800,001-K5M must register for both TOT and VAT.

training_phrases: When is tax clearance certificate required?
responses:
Tax Clearance Certificate required for:
1. Property/motor vehicle transfers
2. Trading licences issuance
3. Mining/exploration licences
4. Government permits/licenses
5. Transactions with suppliers (with exceptions)
6. Professional membership registration

Exemptions:
• Students registering with regulatory bodies
• Applicants not carrying on related business
• Goods/services below ZMW200 per transaction
• Agricultural produce ≤ ZMW10,000 per transaction

TCC valid for specified period, can be cancelled by Commissioner-General.

Advance Income Tax (15%) applies where taxpayer without valid TCC:
1. Exports goods for commercial purposes
2. Remits >$2,000 (or equivalent) outside Zambia through commercial bank

AIT is not final tax - can be credited against liabilities or refunded. Commercial banks deduct AIT and submit returns within 14 days after month-end.

Commercial purposes: Shipment of goods from Zambia to another country with primary intent of generating revenue/trade.
Section 82A(1E) amended: Commissioner-General may now grant exemption from withholding tax on royalties (previously only interest, commission, management/consultancy fees could be exempted).

Section 84 amended:
• Declared agents must remit withheld tax not later than 2 days before due date for respective tax type
• Penalty: 1% of amount for each month/part month of delay
• Subsections renumbered: old (6) becomes (8)

Second Schedule Para 5(l) amended: Exemption from income tax extended to private funds (private equity, hedge funds, venture capital, real estate funds) to extent income distributed to participants. Previously only applicable to approved collective investment schemes.

Presumptive tax on motor vehicles for carriage of persons increased by 20%:
• 64+ seater: K15,552 (was K12,960)
• 50-63 seater: K12,960 (was K10,800)
• 36-49 seater: K10,368 (was K8,640)
• 22-35 seater: K7,776 (was K6,480)
• 18-21 seater: K5,184 (was K4,320)
• 12-17 seater: K2,592 (was K2,160)
• Below 12 seater: K1,296 (was K1,080)

Applies to individuals/partnerships (excludes corporate bodies).

Presumptive tax on betting and gaming:
• Online casino live games: 20% of gross takings
• Online casino machine games: 35% of gross takings
• Casino games (brick & mortar): K5,000 per table
• Online lottery winnings: 35% of net proceeds
• Lottery winnings (brick & mortar): 15% of net proceeds
• Online betting: 25% of gross takings
• Betting (brick & mortar): 15% of gross takings
• Gaming machines: K500 per machine

Note: 15% rate on brick & mortar betting/lottery is now substantive (was temporary for 2023-2024).

Income tax rate changes:
• Non-traditional exports: Increased to 20% from 15% (except farming/agro-processing remains 10%)
• Rental income: Increased to 16% from 12.5% on gross income >K800,000/year
• Manufacturing from copper cathodes: Increased to 20% from 15%

Rental tax bands:
• 0-K12,000: 0%
• K12,001-K800,000: 4%
• Above K800,000: 16%

Charging Schedule Para 5(l): Clarifies five-year reduced rate period (15%) for Special Purpose Vehicle undertaking PPP project applies from first year SPV declares profit and the four consecutive years, regardless of whether profit is made in those subsequent years.

Advance Income Tax rate prescribed at 15% of value for:
1. Import/export for duty purposes
2. Remittances outside Zambia

Effective January 1, 2025.
Withholding tax on winnings from gaming, lotteries and betting reduced to 15% from 20%. Note: 15% rate was temporary for 2023-2024; now permanent.

Property Transfer Tax definition changes:
1. 'Intellectual property' aligned with relevant Acts (Patents, Industrial Designs, Trade Marks, Copyright)
2. 'Building society' defined as per Building Societies Act
3. 'Money-lender' defined as per Money-Lenders Act

Property Transfer Tax rates increased:
• Land: 8% (was 5%)
• Shares: 8% (was 5%)
• Intellectual property: 8% (was 5%)
• Mining right exploration licence: 8% (was 5%)

Other rates unchanged:
• Mining right mining licence: 10%
• Mineral processing licence: 10%
Section 5 amended: Extended use of actual price as realised value for foreclosed property to building societies and money-lenders (previously only financial service providers).

training_phrases: What is the electronic invoicing system?
responses: Smart Invoice is the Zambia Revenue Authority's electronic invoicing system. It is a software-based solution that allows taxpayers to record transactions and issue tax invoices in real-time, ensuring transparency and efficiency in tax administration. From January 1, 2025, input tax claims are restricted to invoices issued through this system.

training_phrases: Can I be exempted from Smart Invoice?
responses: Section 7A(2): Commissioner-General may allow taxable supplier to use document/device/equipment other than electronic invoicing system upon meeting prescribed conditions.
Section 8(6)(c): Clarifies that imported services outside prescribed scope of Cross Border Electronic Services are taxable under reverse VAT mechanism or through appointed agent.

training_phrases: Smart invoice requirement for input tax
responses:
Section 18 amended:
1. Manual invoices and invoices from approved computer package deleted as valid input tax evidence
2. Input tax claims restricted to:
   • Invoices from electronic invoicing system (Smart Invoice)
   • Invoices issued by suppliers exempted from Smart Invoice use
3. Paragraphs renumbered: (c),(d),(e) become (a),(b),(c)

Note: Tax invoices issued outside Smart Invoice up to December 31, 2024 remain valid if meet 90-day validity period.
Section 38A: 'Assistant Commissioner' job title replaced with 'Assistant Director'.

Regulation 3(1)(b) corrected: Open market value of items supplied for promotional/publicity purposes should not exceed K100 (not K100,000) in any accounting year. Correction follows currency rebasing (divide by 1,000).

Regulation 15 corrected: Registered supplier engaged in making zero-rated supplies with turnover not exceeding K200,000 (not K200 million) per annum shall submit tax return every six months. Correction follows currency rebasing.

Regulation 19 amended:
1. Subregulation (2) deleted (penalties for failure to use cash register)
2. Subregulation (3) renumbered as (2)
Regulation 5(3): Taxable supplier must ensure all manually recorded transactions uploaded to electronic invoice system within 72 hours of system being restored.

Regulation 6: Extended provision for claiming input tax to include invoices issued manually or computer-generated by taxable supplier exempted from using electronic invoicing system by Commissioner-General.

Regulation 10: Taxable supplier discontinuing approved invoicing system (for cessation of business or any other reason) must:
1. Submit written request to Commissioner-General within 30 days
2. Keep records from deactivated system for required period
3. Penalty: Up to 30,000 penalty units for non-compliance
Regulation 11: Taxable supplier cannot transfer approved invoicing system registered for own use to another taxable supplier.
SI 93 of 2024: Definition of 'life policy' removed from Value Added Tax (Exemption) Order as it became redundant following deletion of provisions relating to life policies.

Income Tax (Advance Income Tax) Regulations SI 96 of 2024:
1. Bank must deduct AIT on remittances >$2,000 without TCC
2. Submit return within 14 days after month-end
3. Pay tax within 14 days after month-end

Customs and Excise (Suspension) (Internet Services) Regulations SI 91 of 2024:
• Excise duty suspended to 0% on internet services (HS 0000.13.00)
• Applies when supplied by Zambia Research and Education Network to:
  - Public institutions (Examinations Council, NHRA, TEVETA, ZICA)
  - Public research institutions
  - Public secondary schools
  - Public higher education institutions
• Revokes SI 68 of 2023

Insurance Premium Levy (Amendment) Act 28 of 2024:
1. Deleted 'electronic fiscal device' definition
2. Introduced 'electronic invoicing system' definition (as in VAT Act)
3. Requires use of Smart Invoice to record IPL payments and issue tax invoices
Customs and Excise Act Section 2: 'Tribunal' definition changed from Revenue Appeal Tribunal to Tax Appeals Tribunal established under Tax Appeals Tribunal Act 2015.
Section 94(1)(c): Production of electrical energy up to 100kWh for personal/domestic use exempt from licensing and excise duty.
Section 108(10): Licensed manufacturer required to pay estimated assessments/penalties within 3 days (reduced from 5 days) following notice.
Section 155(4): Clarifies use of excisable value in charging general penalties for licensed manufacturer of excisable goods. Subsections (4) and (5) renumbered as (5) and (6).

Excise duty increases:
1. Non-alcoholic beverages (HS 2009): K1.00/litre (was K0.60)
2. Mineral waters (HS 2201): K1.00/litre (was K0.30)
3. Other beverages (HS 2202): K1.00/litre (was K0.30)
4. Tobacco products: K452 per mille/kg (was K400)
5. Fuel: Petrol K2.34, Diesel K0.75, Kerosene K0.54, Other fuels K1.05

Note: Locally produced non-alcoholic beverages (HS 2202) pay one-tenth (was one-sixth) of specific duty rate.

Mobile Money Transaction Levy Act definitions:
• 'Electronic money': Monetary value electronically represented by claim on mobile money service provider
• 'Merchant': Person registered with ZRA accepting electronic money for goods/services (excludes betting)
• 'Person-to-person transfer': Transfer from one person to another
• 'Mobile money service provider': Entity authorized by Bank of Zambia to issue electronic money

Mobile Money Transaction Levy administration:
• Levy collected by mobile money service provider
• Paid by sender of electronic money
• Returns due within 10 days after month-end
• Levy remittance within 10 days after month-end
• Penalty: K100,000 penalty units per month for non-compliance
• Commissioner-General may waive penalty

Mobile Money Transaction Levy applies to:
• Person-to-person transfers
• Payments to Government
• Payments from Government
• Utility bill payments
• Payments to merchants
• Bank-to-wallet transfers

Minister may exempt persons by statutory instrument (none issued yet).

Mobile money service providers must:
• Keep records for 6 years
• Commissioner-General may extend period
• Penalty: K200,000 penalty units for non-compliance
• Commissioner-General may waive penalty

Commissioner-General may:
• Enter premises without prior notice
• Inspect records/articles
• Verify returns
• Require additional information

Mobile Money Transaction Levy Act 2023 repealed. Transitional provisions:
• Service providers remit levies to ZRA
• Bank of Zambia transmits records/returns from repealed Act to ZRA

Benefits convertible to money/money's worth:
• Taxable under PAYE
• Allowable deduction for employer

Examples: Payment of private bills (electricity, rent, school fees), housing allowances, cash allowances.

'Money or money's worth': Expenditure of direct monetary value (money, securities, property, services reducible to money's value).

Employer-owned accommodation rented to employee:
• Housing allowance taxable under PAYE
• Rental income liable to tax for employer
• Rent should reflect economic value based on structure type and location

Benefits NOT convertible to money/money's worth:
• Not taxable on employee
• NOT deductible for employer (Section 44(l))

Factors (any 3+ apply):
1. Not convertible to actual money
2. Not convertible to pecuniary benefit
3. Not disposable/transferable
4. Not owned by employee
5. Restrictive terms/conditions
6. Use it or forfeit

Examples: Free housing (cannot lease), airtime (sole use), fuel (specific car/type).

Housing tax treatment:
A. Employer-owned housing provided to employee:
   • Free housing: Disallow 37% of employee's taxable income
   • Below-market rent: Disallow 37% of taxable income
   • Independent valuation may be used

B. Leased housing provided to employee:
   • Single occupant: Rentals added to emoluments (PAYE)
   • Multiple occupants: Total rentals disallowed for employer

Utilities (electricity, water, security) not included in 'free housing'.

Below market price provision:
• Services below market: Difference disallowed for employer
• Goods below market: Difference taxable under PAYE (employer may gross up)

Motor vehicle provided on personal-to-holder basis (business & personal use):
• 2800cc+: K57,600/year disallowed
• 1800-2800cc: K43,200/year disallowed
• Below 1800cc: K25,200/year disallowed

Personal-to-holder: Vehicle for both business/personal use with employer paying all running/maintenance expenses.

All cash allowances taxable under PAYE:
• Education allowance
• Housing allowance
• Transport/fuel allowance
• Domestic utility allowances
• Commuted car allowance
• Settling in allowance
• Professional qualification allowances

Payments exempt from PAYE:
• Ex-gratia to spouse/child/dependant of deceased employee
• Medical expenses paid/incurred by employer
• Funeral expenses paid by employer
• Local Authority sitting allowances for Councillors
• Labour Day awards (cash/kind)
• Per diem/travel allowances while working away from office

Entertainment/hospitality/gifts expenses NOT allowable except:
1. Business providing entertainment/hospitality (hotels, restaurants)
2. Free entertainment for publicity (free seats for critics)
3. Employee entertainment (Christmas party, business trip meals)
4. Advertisement gifts ≤ K100 to any person in charge year (excess disallowed)

Entertainment allowances: Taxable under PAYE, disallowed for employer.

Employer-provided refreshments/canteen meals/food rations:
• Not taxable on employee (cannot convert to money's worth)
• Fully disallowed for employer (Section 44(l))

Exception: Where legal obligation to provide meals, cost may be deductible.

Cessation of employment payments:

EXEMPT (pension benefits):
• Pension
• Refund of employee pension contributions
• Withdrawal of employer pension contributions
• Gratuity
• Redundancy pay
• Severance pay/compensation for loss of office
• Salary in lieu of notice
• Repatriation allowance
• Service bonuses eligible only at end of employment

TAXABLE (PAYE):
• Monthly salary
• Commutation of accrued leave days
• Accrued service bonuses (linked to performance)
Payments on termination due to medical grounds (permanent incapacity certified by registered medical practitioner/institution) are exempt from tax.
Advances against gratuity, pensions, and employee pension withdrawals by individuals continuing in employment are exempt (constitute pension benefits).
Settling in allowances (by any name) paid to new employees or employees on transfer constitute employment income and are taxable under PAYE.

Rural enterprise incentive:
• Reduction by one-fifth of tax payable
• First five charge years of operation
• Location: Area not declared city/municipality (excluding Kafue township)
• Excludes mining/mineral processing

Example: K10,000 taxable income
• Normal tax: K3,000
• Incentive: K600 (1/5 of K3,000)
• Final tax: K2,400

Share forfeiture/surrender:
• No Property Transfer Tax (not a transfer)
• Shareholder not required to submit provisional return
• Company selling forfeited/surrendered shares: Submit provisional return, account for PTT
• PTT assessment based on market value at transfer time

Conditions for forfeiture/surrender:
1. No consideration
2. Shares not paid up for
3. Call on shares not paid for

PAYE refundable when:
1. Errors (payroll, wrong bands, arithmetic, taxing exempt income)
2. Unemployment before year-end
3. Eligible deductions (donations to approved PBOs ≤15% income)

Example: Employee earning K14,000/month stops in August:
• Annual income: K112,000
• Annual tax due: K12,952
• Tax paid (8 months): K22,448
• Refund: K9,496

Apply using ZRA prescribed forms at year-end.

Donations to approved Public Benefit Organisations:
• Deduction ≤15% of taxable income for charge year
• Claim at year-end using prescribed forms

Example: K150,000 income, K25,000 donation
• Max deduction: K22,500 (15% of K150,000)
• Taxable income: K127,500
• Tax due: K18,687
• Tax paid: K27,012
• Refund: K8,325

Disability-related tax benefits:

EMPLOYEES:
• Tax credit: K7,200/year (K600/month)
• Granted by employer computing PAYE
• Must be registered with Zambia Agency for Persons with Disabilities
• Refund limited to tax actually paid if not claimed during year

EMPLOYERS:
• Deduction: K2,000/year for each person with disability employed full-time
• Employee must be registered with Zambia Agency
• Deductible in computing business profits

Non-resident haulage contractors:
1. Zambia to Country A: Zambian source, income tax + WHT (not final)
2. Country A to B: No Zambian source, no tax
3. Country C to Zambia: No Zambian source, no tax
4. Within Zambia: Zambian source, WHT deductible
   • If PE created: 30% tax on attributed profits

WHT on non-resident contractors: 20% (final tax)

training_phrases: Working in Zambia for foreign company
responses:
Employment income earned in Zambia subject to PAYE regardless of:
• Employer's residence
• Payment location
• Employee's residence

Legal basis: Section 14 (tax at source) + Section 18(1)(b) (deemed Zambian source for employment/services in Zambia).

Migration from Turnover Tax to Income Tax:
• Notify Commissioner-General immediately upon exceeding K5M threshold
• Continue paying TOT until year-end
• Deregistered from TOT at beginning of next charge year
• File annual Income Tax Return by June 21 for preceding year
• ZRA assesses under income tax, grants TOT credits

Note: Change occurs at beginning of next year unless Commissioner-General specifies other date.

Non-monetary gaming prizes (e.g., car):
• Net proceeds = gross proceeds minus prize value
• Prize value determined by Commissioner-General
• Presumptive tax applied to net proceeds

One-time lottery organizers:
• NO registration if: Promotes business, entry requires purchasing products
• MUST register if: Sells lottery tickets

Slot route operations: Gaming machine owner (not location owner) accounts for Presumptive Tax (K500/machine) and WHT (15%).

Applying for Double Taxation Treaty Relief (Limited Deduction Direction):
Submit to Assistant Director - International Tax Policy:
1. Contract copy (management, royalties, loan agreement, etc.)
2. Completed Form WHT-3 from www.zra.org.zm
3. Tax Residence Certificate OR Part 11 of Form WHT-3 certified by foreign tax authority

For dividends: Signed board resolution

Commissioner-General issues LDD to apply reduced treaty rates.

VAT treatment of ramp services:
• Equipment hire for passenger embark/disembark: Standard-rated
• Loading cargo for export: Standard-rated (was zero-rated)
• Offloading imports: Standard-rated
• Ancillary transit services: Standard-rated (except transshipment)
• Transshipment: Zero-rated (moving cargo between vessels under customs control)
• Cold chain services: Standard-rated
• Clearing/forwarding: Standard-rated

Finance lease VAT apportionment:
• Principal (capital): Standard-rated
• Interest: Exempt
• Taxable supplier must apportion input tax using methods in Second Schedule to VAT Administrative Rules
• Applies to input tax on asset and related expenses

Imported services (reverse VAT):
• Applicable if imported by VAT-registered person
• NOT applicable if:
  1. Service is exempt
  2. Importer not eligible for VAT registration (exempt supplies or privileged person)
  3. Taxable supplier not registered (turnover below threshold)
• Foreign provider must provide proof of tax payment in export country

Incorrect VAT charges:
• VAT charged on exempt supplies: Recoverable by Government
• VAT charged by non-registered supplier: Recoverable as tax due
• Must be shown on invoice as tax chargeable

Valid tax invoice for input claim:
• Must have mandatory features prescribed in Commissioner-General's Rules
• Required at point of filing return

VAT Zero-Rating Local Purchase Orders:
• Privileged persons can purchase standard-rated supplies at 0% using VAT LPOs
• LPO must be availed at time of purchase
• Without LPO: Supplier must charge 16% VAT (not refundable even if LPO provided later)
• Goods supplied out of bond: VAT LPOs not applicable

Insurance broker commission:
• NOT subject to Insurance Premium Levy
• IPL charged on insurance premiums only
• Commission earned for arranging insurance services is brokerage income

Clearing goods using Government vouchers:
• Government pays duties/taxes using vouchers
• Commonly used for clearing motor vehicles from bonded warehouses
• Goods physically in Zambia but not cleared for local consumption
• Process similar to border clearance
• VAT LPOs not applicable for goods out of bond

Tourism Levy penalty example:
Declared: Accommodation K1,500 + Conference K1,000 = K2,500 × 1.5% = K37.50
Actual: Accommodation K3,750 + Conference K1,500 = K5,250 × 1.5% = K78.75
Underdeclared: K41.25
Penalty: 5% of omitted amount (K2,750) = K137.50
Total payable: K137.50 + K41.25 = K178.75
